name: Addition and subtraction with negative numbers 2

skills.name: Carry out addition problems involving two negative integers
Carry out addition problems involving one negative decimal
Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers
Carry out a subtraction problem with positive integers where the answer is less than 0

explanations.A: To calculate (−5) ＋ (−2) start at −5 on the number line, then move 2 in the negative direction. This will take you to the answer, −7.
explanations.B: I think you might have thought that 2 negatives makes a plus. Start at -5 on the number line and then move -2
explanations.C: Remember you are starting at -5 on the number line. Think about the direction you will move if you are adding a negative on
explanations.D: Remember you are adding -2. What direction will you move on the number line?

explanations.A: Remember you are adding -4. What direction will you move on the number line?
explanations.B: Remember you are starting at -9 on the number line. Think about the direction you will move if you are adding a negative on
explanations.C: I think you might have thought that 2 negatives makes a plus. Start at -9 on the number line and then move -4
explanations.D: To calculate (−9) ＋ (−4) start at −9 on the number line, then move 4 in the negative direction. This will take you to the answer, −13.

explanations.A: The number of steps from 8 to −3 is −11. This is made up of a missing value, a, and −2. So a ＋ (−2) = −11. This means that the missing value must be −9.
explanations.B: I think you might have thought the 'a' arrow starts at 0. Think about where you would be after you went 2 back rom 8, and how much further you need to go to get to -3
explanations.C: I think you have counted numbers rather than jumps. How many jumps would you need to do to get back to -3?
explanations.D: Almost, did you count the 0 when you were jumping backwards?

explanations.A: I think you have found 4 - 5, rather than the number of jumps back you will still have to do to get to -5. .
explanations.B: The number of steps from 4 to −5 is −9. This is made up of a missing value, a, and −3. So a ＋ (−3) = −9. This means that the missing value must be −6.
explanations.C: Almost, did you count the 0 when you were jumping backwards?
explanations.D: I think you have counted numbers rather than jumps. How many jumps would you need to do to get back to -5?

explanations.A: Not quite, the arrow doesn't start at 0. You have started at -7 and moved 5 jumps up the number line. Think about where you are, and how many jumps you have to do to get back to -5?
explanations.B: I think you have counted numbers rather than jumps. How many jumps would you need to do to get to -5?
explanations.C: I think you have found where the red arrow starts. How far from here do you need to go back to get to -5?
explanations.D: Starting at −7 and adding on 5 gives −2, so this is the value indicated at the start of arrow b. From this starting point, the question is what number do you subtract from −2 to get to −5. The answer is −3, so b has a value of −3.

explanations.A: Not quite, the arrow hasn't started at 0. The arrow starts 10 forward from -12, so how far do you need to jump back to -7?
explanations.B: Starting at −12 and adding on 10 gives −2, so this is the value indicated at the start of arrow b. From this starting point, the question is what number do you subtract from −2 to get to −7. The answer is −5, so b has a value of −5.
explanations.C: I think you have found where the red arrow starts. How far from here do you need to go back to get to -7?
explanations.D: I think you have counted numbers rather than jumps. How many jumps would you need to do to get to -7?

explanations.A: I think you have found 3 less than -1.4. 3 more would move up the number line
explanations.B: Not quite. Think about how far it is to get to 0, and then how much further we need to go beyond 0 so we've moved 3 in total.
explanations.C: Start at -1.4 We add 1.4 to get up to 0, and then we need to add on another 1.6 so that we have added 3 in total. This will take us to 1.6
explanations.D: I think you have added on 0.3 rather than 3. You might want to split the addition up and go to 0 first, and then see how much further you need to go so you've added 3 in total.

explanations.A: I think you have found 5 less than -2.6. 5 more would move up the number line
explanations.B: Not quite. Think about how far it is to get to 0, and then how much further we need to go beyond 0 so we've moved 5 in total.
explanations.C: Start at -2.6 We add 2.6 to get up to 0, and then we need to add on another 2.4 so that we have added 5 in total. This will take us to 2.4
explanations.D: I think you have added on 0.5 rather than 5. You might want to split the addition up and go to 0 first, and then see how much further you need to go so you've added 5 in total.

explanations.A: Nearly. Which calculation(s) represent the starting point, the direction and the distance?
explanations.B: Nearly. Which calculation(s) represent the starting point, the direction and the distance?
explanations.C: Tom starts at 15. Because the direction of the arrow indicates 'subtract', he calculates 15 − 20 = −5. Katie has a starting point of −5. Because she is going in the opposite direction to that indicated by the arrow, the value needs a negative sign, so −(−20). This is the same as ＋20, so Katie's statement: −5＋ 20 = 15 is also correct.
explanations.D: Not quite. Which calculation(s) represent the starting point, the direction and the distance?

explanations.A: Nearly. Which calculation(s) represent the starting point, the direction and the distance?
explanations.B: Nearly. Which calculation(s) represent the starting point, the direction and the distance?
explanations.C: Jo starts at 12. Because the direction of the arrow indicates 'subtract', she calculates 12 − 15 = −3. Paul has a starting point of −3. Because he is going in the opposite direction to that indicated by the arrow, the value needs a negative sign, so −(−15). This is the same as ＋15, so Jo's statement: −3＋ 15 = 12 is also correct.
explanations.D: Not quite. Which calculation(s) represent the starting point, the direction and the distance?
